item.description: Introduction Proofs demonstrate the absolute truth of a statement, and should aim to achieve three things â€‚- Correctness

item.title: AEECO - Market Efficiency
item.description: Surplus Consumer Surplus Difference between what a consumer is prepared to pay and what they actually pay in the market.

item.title: Case
item.description: Exercise 1 A CD manufacturing company charges Multimedia companies $6.50 per CD if they create less than 1000 copies. If the company requires more than 10000, they only pay $5.

item.title: Chapter 1
item.description: What is Economics? Economics deals with two basic facts. People are faced with limited resources People have unlimited wants

item.title: Chapter 2
item.description: Summary Notes - CH2 The Role of Markets Economic systems exist to deal with the economic problem, in order to answer the basic economic problem A market is said to exist when buyers and sellers exchange goods, services or resources.

item.title: Chapter 3
item.description: Price Elasticity Price Elasticity of demand Price elasticity measures the responsiveness of quantity demanded to changes in price Price elasticity of demand (Ed) can be calculated by Percentage Change $$Ed = \frac{% change \space in \space quantity \space demanded}{% \space change \space in \space price}$$ Price Elastic Goods The quantity demanded of the product is relatively responsive to changes in price.

item.title: Chapter 4
item.description: Market Efficiency Efficiency is producing the goods that society wants at the lowest possible price. Surplus Consumer Surplus Difference between what a consumer is prepared to pay and what they actually pay in the market.

item.title: Chapter 5
item.description: Market Power Imperfect Markets [!IMPORTANT] Imperfect Markets Imperfect markets are not in the course outline The model of demand and supply applies to a competitive market.

item.title: Computer Science Index
item.description: Computer Science In progress Programming Please note that these notes are incomplete The are also not really being updated as computer science is a dead subject

item.title: Demand and Supply
item.description: Demand The quantity of a good or service that consumers are willing and able to buy at each price in a particular point in time.

item.title: Elasticty
item.description: Price Elasticity Price Elasticity of demand Price elasticity measures the responsiveness of quantity demanded to changes in price Price elasticity of demand (Ed) can be calculated by Percentage Change $$Ed = \frac{% change \space in \space quantity \space demanded}{% \space change \space in \space price}$$ Price Elastic Goods The quantity demanded of the product is relatively responsive to changes in price.

item.title: Externalities
item.description: Externalities Key Concepts Demand: Private benefits that consumers receive Supply: Private costs of production MPC (Marginal Private Cost): Costs to producers of producing one more unit of a good MSC (Marginal Social Cost): Costs to society of producing one more unit of a good MPB (Marginal Private Benefit): Benefits to consumers from consuming one more unit of a good MSB (Marginal Social Benefit): Benefits to society from consuming one more unit of a good

item.title: Functions
item.description: A Function is a reusable block of code. INCOMPLETE

item.title: Intro
item.description: Variables - Are temporary member address locations Global - A variable that can be accessed anywhere in the code Local - A variable that is only available in a single function or part

item.title: Intro
item.description: Opportunity cost Opportunity cost is the alternative option in a choice. Positive economics is the testing and developing economic theory - subjects that are testable.

item.title: Iterations
item.description: Exercise 1 Print the integers from 1 to 100 1 2 3 4 5 BEGIN FOR i = 1 TO 100: OUTPUT(i) NEXT END 1 2 for i in range(100): print(i) Exercise 2 You have been contracted to write a program that will accept from the user the rainfall (in Millimeters) for each day of the week and then show total and average rainfall for that week.

item.title: Journal - Computer Science
item.description: Term 2 W1L1 Continued work on our project that is due in on Wednesday W1L2 Messed around as usual. No one was productive.

item.title: Journal - Economics
item.description: Term 2 W1L1 Finally got our extended responses back. Class average was 12/20, cohort average was 14.5/20. Started learning about externalities in the last 15 minutes.

item.title: Journal - English
item.description: Term 2 W1L1 Did a practice composing in response to some questions. Our entire table did abstractism for a question about writing a creative text in a particular genre but an atypical setting.

item.title: Journal - Methods
item.description: Term 2 W1L1 Did some very basic questions on sets. I had lots of great entertainment in the form of Edward trying to get an email client on Linux for the entire period.

item.title: Journal - Physics
item.description: Term 2 W1L1 Learnt about ultrasound. W1L2 Did validation test. Our class got 20 minutes to do it when other classes got 45.

item.title: Journal - Specialist
item.description: Term 2 W1L1 Did test revision.

item.title: Market Failure
item.description: Causes of Market Failure Classification of Goods Rival Does the consumption by one party reduce the supply available for another?

item.title: Pseudocode
item.description: Problem Write the code for a program that will add 3 numbers entered by the user and then determine if the sum of the numbers is greater than 15.
